title: What is the standard number of bars in a jail cell? Does it vary from prison to prison or is it standardised? - Quora

response.answer_text: Most prisons and many jails don’t have bars on the cells. The doors are typically solid with the exception of a narrow window from roughly where the door handle (which is recessed into the door) and maybe 6 inches from the top of the door. Cells also have a window that is a few inches wide and maybe 30 inches tall in the outer wall. Enough to allow some light to enter, but not enough to give much of a view and definitely not wide enough to get through even if you could break the “glass” out. The “glass” is usually lexan - a polycarbonate substitute that has 250 times greater impact resistance than glass and 30 times that of acrylic.

Before new Prisons were built in Australia the old one's date back to colonization by the British. In the State I served my sentence in 3 maximum security prisons were identical with each other. In the cell windows there were 2 bars. The windows were far too small for even a small inmate to attempt to escape from after removing the 2 bars in the window.
